answers.answer: HiWelcome to the MedHelp forum!Actually a subcutaneous skin nodule—the size of a pea and firm, is usually due to a neurofibroma (connective ad nerve tissue), a ganglion cyst or a lymph node. Tick bite is one possibility and if you live in an area prone for tick bites, then Lyme's disease should be ruled out by appropriate tests. Pseudolymphoma is another possibility which causes persistent inflammatory nodules. The good thing is that they are usually without symptoms and disappear on their own by 8-9 months. These can be due to calcinosis or calcium deposits you have received calcium supplements in the past. An autoimmune condition called granuloma annulare is another possibility and hence immunoglobulins and other tests for autoimmune disorders of which rheumatoid arthritis too is one should be looked into. Sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, pseudorheumatoid disease, foreign body granulomas, leprosies, leishmaniasis (parasitic disease caused by bite of sand fly), lupus, hypothyroidism, diabetes, and deep fungal infections should also be looked into.You may not be having any of these and it could just be a neurofibroma or a cyst or lymphnode. However, please confirm with a doctor who can examine you. Take care!

question: Hello, I am a 31 year old female.  I have had a small pea sized lump on the back left side of my neck for at least 2-3 years now.  I never noticed it before but it could have been there.  It has not changed in size.  It is not rock hard and I can move it around a little.  It does not hurt to push on it.  I tend to get lots of knots in my neck.  I was hit from behind in a car accident about 4 years ago and ever since I get lots of knots in my neck.  I have had blood work done and everything is normal. Should I be worried and have it checked out?
title: small pea sized lump in neck
